The Unreasonable Ineffectiveness of the Deeper Layers

Finds minimal degradation of performance of LLMs on various QA benchmarks until after a large fraction (up to half) of the layers are removed
arxiv.org/abs/2403.17887
Why doesn’t hyperparameter tuning catch these kinds of things?

They were pruning layers after pre-training with optional "healing" (fine-tuning after pruning) afterwards.

The fact that the final model is reachable theoretically doesn't mean pre-training with the same shallow model architecture from the beginning will ever get you there...

In a recent podcast,

entities.name: Robin Hanson
entities.text: @robinhanson

argued that progress in automating tasks with computers has been relatively steady and slow over the last 70 years, which he interprets as showing that AIs won't automate most human labor soon. However, I find his argument weak. Here's why🧵

entities.text: In the podcast, he helpfully provides a model of task automation with computers, which he seems to find plausible. You can read this model of automation in the attached quote.

user.name: Matthew Barnett
user.description:
I share things.

Married to @natalia__coelho

entities.text: If Hanson were correct, and compute grew at a steady exponential pace, then we would indeed see relatively steady AI automation over a long period. However, he's wrong because compute for AI has actually grown faster-than-exponentially over the last 70 years (see image).

user.name: Matthew Barnett
user.description:
I share things.

Married to @natalia__coelho

entities.text: From 1960 to 2010, compute used for milestone AI projects grew by roughly 8 orders of magnitude. However, from just 2010 to 2023, compute grew by 9 orders of magnitude. This recent rapid growth in compute was enabled mostly by growth in investments, rather hardware progress.

user.name: Matthew Barnett
user.description:
I share things.

Married to @natalia__coelho

entities.text:
How much longer can the trend in increasing investments since 2010 continue? Potentially quite a bit longer.

The largest AI projects so far have cost only roughly $100M to train. Given the vast economic promise from AI, it seems potentially worth spending several OOMs more.

user.name: Matthew Barnett
user.description:
I share things.

Married to @natalia__coelho

entities.text: NVIDIA currently sells their GPUs used for AI training at an incredibly high markup (see screenshot). If we could buy GPUs at their production cost, it seems likely that even without additional hardware progress, the price of computation could fall by ~another order of magnitude.

user.name: Matthew Barnett
user.description:
I share things.

Married to @natalia__coelho

entities.text: My own basic calculations suggest that, given the potential for increased investment and hardware progress, we could very soon move through a large fraction of the remaining compute gap between the current frontier models and the literal amount of computation used by evolution.

user.name: Matthew Barnett
user.description:
I share things.

Married to @natalia__coelho

entities.text: Now, I agree: if AI capable of automating most human labor is not attained within another ~6 OOMs of compute above our current frontier, we may see a sudden slowdown in AI progress starting in the late-2020s to mid-2030s. But 6 OOMs of compute is a lot.

user.name: Matthew Barnett

entities.text: Given these reasons, I think it is wrong to confidently dismiss the potential for widespread automation within 10 years. Robin Hanson should consider the evidence that a lot of AI progress has been concentrated recently, and this rapid pace could continue for a while longer.

That graph is very misleading.  Deep Blue evaluated about 100 million positions per second, with 8,500 features, over a period of many hours, so conservatively about 10^16 operations, probably more like 10^17

It's often elided from such graphs, usually with the excuse that it wasn't a trained ML system. It actually was - there were linear weights found for each feature - but it's hard to find just how much tuning was done of those.   I suspect the reason its elided is often that people want to go "gosh, wow, look at the increase in compute", and Deep Blue violates that desired narrative...

entities.text:
[CL] The Unreasonable Ineffectiveness of the Deeper Layers
A Gromov, K Tirumala, H Shapourian, P Glorioso, D A. Roberts [Meta FAIR & Cisco & Zyphra] (2024)
arxiv.org/abs/2403.17887

- The paper empirically studies a simple layer-pruning strategy for popular pretrained LLMs like GPT-3, finding minimal degradation in performance on QA benchmarks after removing up to half the layers.  

- The method identifies the optimal block of layers to prune based on similarity of representations across layers. After pruning, a small amount of efficient finetuning is used to "heal" the damage.

- The robustness to deleting layers implies current pretraining methods don't properly leverage deeper layers, or that shallow layers play a critical role in storing knowledge.  

- Pruning decreases model footprint and speeds up inference linearly with the number of layers removed. It complements other efficient finetuning methods like quantization and adapters.

- The paper combines layer pruning with quantization and adapters so each experiment runs on a single GPU, accessible to open source community.

user.name: Dan Roberts
user.description: RL Scientist @OpenAI. Prev. co-founder @diffeo, acquired by @salesforce // co-authored The Principles of Deep Learning Theory // studied gravity.

entities.text:
🪜Today's LLM paper review The Unreasonable Ineffectiveness of the Deeper Layers (March 2024) investigates the effectiveness of deeper layers in large language models. The authors propose a layer-pruning strategy that identifies and removes layers based on their similarity, measured by the angular distance between their representations. Experiments on the Llama-2-70B model show that pruning deeper layers leads to minimal performance degradation on downstream tasks until a critical fraction is removed.

✂️ To address the performance drop after pruning, the authors introduce a "healing" process involving quantization and fine-tuning. This process significantly reduces the loss increase caused by layer dropping and restores performance on question-answering benchmarks. The paper also explores a simpler pruning heuristic that drops the deepest layers, followed by healing, achieving comparable results.

🌡️The findings suggest that deeper layers in LLMs may be less effective than shallower ones, and that pruning strategies should consider both continuous measures and downstream task performance. The paper highlights the importance of understanding the relationship between model layers and their impact on tasks, guiding future pruning strategies for improved efficiency in large language models.

entities.text:
Efficiency Breakthroughs in LLMs: Combining Quantization, LoRA, and Pruning for Scaled-down Inference and Pre-training

Quick read:
marktechpost.com/2024/03/28/eff…

Researchers from Meta FAIR, UMD, Cisco, Zyphra, MIT, and Sequoia Capital examine a layer-pruning approach for popular open-weight pretrained LLMs. They find minimal performance degradation occurs on question-answering benchmarks until a significant fraction (up to half) of the layers are removed. Their method involves identifying optimal layers for pruning based on similarity across layers and then performing a small amount of finetuning using parameter-efficient finetuning (PEFT) methods like quantization and Low-Rank Adapters (QLoRA). This approach significantly reduces computational resources for finetuning while improving inference memory and latency. The study suggests that current pretraining methods may not effectively utilize deeper layers.

Pruning, a technique for reducing the size of trained machine-learning models, involves removing unnecessary parameters. Early methods focused on individual parameter removal, leading to irregular sparsification patterns. Structured pruning emerged to remove parameter groups, enhancing practicality. Recent efforts extend pruning to transformer models, exploring various elimination approaches. While BERT-style models often drop final layers, GPT-style models exhibit nuanced behavior. Model distillation offers an alternative size reduction method. Parameter-efficient finetuning methods like LoRA and QLoRA complement pruning. Deep studies on LLM properties corroborate the findings, highlighting the potential for layer pruning while underscoring layer-dependent knowledge storage.
#ArtificialIntelligence
#LLMs

The Key takeaways from this very nice paper - 

" The model’s memory footprint and inference time decreases linearly with the number of removed layers.4 This makes layer pruning a powerful tool, especially if the model’s performance is robust to dropping layers.

• All the efficiency methods – pruning, PEFT and quantization – can be effectively combined with each other. Thus, in this work each experiment was performed on a single A100 GPU and is easily accessible to the open source and academic communities.

• The robustness of models to removing the deeper layers, the sharp transition in performance on downstream knowledge tasks (e.g. MMLU and BoolQ), and the smooth behavior of the autoregressive loss with respect to those pruning fractions, altogether suggest that the shallow layers may play a critical role in storing knowledge."

entities.text:
The Unreasonable Ineffectiveness of the Deeper Layers

・LLM内の類似しているパラメーターを削減しても質問応答タスクの性能がほとんど低下しなかった
・小さいモデルでもレイヤーの20%程度まで刈り込み(pruning)しても大丈夫だった
・刈りこんだ後、少量の微調整(healing)を行うことで性能低下を更に抑え事が出来た

つまり、刈りこみと量子化とヒーリングを行う事で、巨大なモデルをより小さいハードウェアで効率的に実行できる可能性が開かれた！

と言う事であり、個人的にはありがたいお話だったのですが、巨大なモデルの方が注目を集めるのであまり話題になっておらず続報(コードなど)はまだ見かけてません

この結果により「モデルの浅い層(入力に近い層)や中間層は知識の保持に重要な役割を果たしており、深い層は比較的冗長である可能性」と推測されるわけですが、影響がゼロなわけではなく、おそらく「全体的な文脈を把握し、その文脈理解を維持する能力」がごっそり抜けおちてしまっているんだろうな、とは思います。

それと、healingって事前学習的なアプローチで、C4データセットを使って次の単語を予測させる事をQLoRAで軽めにやってるようなのですが、その際のrank設定が凄い面白くて最初64から開始して性能が悪いと下げるって形で探っています

網羅的に調べたわけではないようなのですが一部のモデルは
Mistral-7Bがrank 4
Llama-2-7Bがrank 2
Llama-2-70Bがrank 8
と非常に低い値を使ったとの事

もしかしたらC4よりこれらのモデルが使った事前学習データが優れているので、ランクが高すぎるとC4に過学習してしまって性能が下がってしまうのかもしれないとの事

ベースとなる学習率が結構高めの値を使っているように見えるので、その辺りも影響しているのかもしれませんが、ハイジのお爺さんにベストプラクティスを聞いてみたい気持ちでいっぱいです

entities.text:
A very surprising study. The authors announce the following: it is possible to remove at least one fifth of a LLM, and still maintain high performances !

How do they do that?
1- Pick a number n of layers you want to prune (2/8)

user.name: Axel Darmouni
user.description: Engineer @CentraleSupelec P22 | Data Scientist

entities.text:
2- Compute for each intermediate layer l, a distance between the output of the layers l and l+n, for all examples within a dataset accordingly chosen
3- Remove the n layers starting from l* where the average distance is minimal (3/8)

user.name: Axel Darmouni
user.description: Engineer @CentraleSupelec P22 | Data Scientist

entities.text:
4- Perform PEFT to whip the model back into shape 

Each experiment was performed on a single A100 GPU, which is pretty big. This method is studied on the MMLU dataset. (4/8)

user.name: Axel Darmouni
user.description: Engineer @CentraleSupelec P22 | Data Scientist

entities.text:
The results are impressive, as stated before: removing more than a fifth of the layers maintain model performance in the 5-shot setting!

The PEFT Healing does appear to have an importance in setting the model straight, otherwise it is way more unstable on validation. (5/8)

user.name: Axel Darmouni
user.description: Engineer @CentraleSupelec P22 | Data Scientist

entities.text: It would also appear that surprisingly, the « most useless » layers that are pruned, except in the case of the Qwen series, happen to be in the end of the model. (6/8)

entities.text:
📢📢 New paper: We can remove up to 40% of the layers in some LLMs (like Llama-2) without losing efficiency.

The idea is to do a type of smart pruning combined with other tricks.

💡What is pruning?
Eliminating layers to reduce the size of the network. It improves the memory footprint and inference time.

💡Which layers should we remove?
The standard approach is to prune layers randomly. However, here they computed the embedding similarity between different layers to identify the optimal layers to prune.

💡What other tricks can be used?
Healing: finetuning part of the layer to correct the loss in performance introduced when pruning.
Quantization: Reduce the precision of the weights, for example, from 16-bit to 4-bit.

Results for Llama-2:
- Memory footprint: from 140GB to 17.5 GB.
- Layer reduction: 45%-55% of layers.

Overall, the idea is very interesting.

There are many opportunities to optimize the architectures we have in current LLMs.

"From a scientific perspective, the robustness of these LLMs to the deletion of layers implies either that current pretraining methods are not properly leveraging the parameters in the deeper layers of the network or that the shallow layers play a critical role in storing knowledge."

pruning deep learning models was a thing back in the pre-llm days when computer vision models were making it into production

but what about pruning in llms - could the same effect of "fewer layers, similar performance" hold true?

looks like it!

We empirically study a simple layer-pruning strategy for popular families of openweight pretrained LLMs, finding minimal degradation of performance on different question-answering benchmarks until after a large fraction (up to half) of the layers are removed. To prune these models, we identify the optimal block of layers to prune by considering similarity across layers; then, to “heal” the damage, we perform a small amount of finetuning. In particular, we use parameter-efficient finetuning (PEFT) methods, specifically quantization and Low Rank Adapters (QLoRA), such that each of our experiments can be performed on a single A100 GPU. From a practical perspective, these results suggest that layer pruning methods can complement other PEFT strategies to further reduce computational resources of finetuning on the one hand, and can improve the memory and latency of inference on the other hand. From a scientific perspective, the robustness of these LLMs to the deletion of layers implies either that current pretraining methods are not properly leveraging the parameters in the deeper layers of the network or that the shallow layers play a critical role in storing knowledge.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: 我々は、オープンウェイト事前訓練LLMの一般的なファミリーに対する単純なレイヤープルーニング戦略を実証的に研究し、様々な質問応答ベンチマークにおいて、レイヤーの大部分（最大半分）が削除されるまで、性能の劣化が最小限であることを発見した。これらのモデルを刈り込むには、レイヤー間の類似性を考慮することで、刈り込むレイヤーの最適なブロックを特定する。次に、ダメージを「癒す」ために、少量の微調整を行う。特に、パラメータ効率の良いファインチューニング（PEFT）手法、特に量子化と低ランクアダプター（QLoRA）を使用し、各実験をA100 GPU1台で実行できるようにしています。実用的な観点からは、これらの結果は、レイヤープルーニング法が他のPEFT戦略を補完し、一方では微調整の計算資源をさらに削減し、他方では推論のメモリとレイテンシを改善できることを示唆している。科学的な観点からは、これらのLLMが層の削除に頑健であることは、現在の事前学習法がネットワークの深い層のパラメータを適切に活用していないか、浅い層が知識の保存に重要な役割を果たしていることを示唆している。

entities.text:
SoTA LLMs typically exhibit 99%+ non-zero activations, but it turns out that they are still intrinsically quite sparse!

We introduce CATS, a simple post-training technique that achieves 50% activation sparsity for MLP layers with almost no drop in downstream evals, while requiring little to no finetuning! With our custom GPU kernels, we leverage this sparsity to achieve 15% improvement in end-to-end generation latency for both Mistral-7B and Llama-7B models.

Work led by

user.name: Azalia Mirhoseini
user.description: Assistant Professor of CS at Stanford, Senior Staff Research Scientist at Google DeepMind. Prev: Anthropic, Google Brain

entities.text: Currently, models like Mistral and Llama-2 use activation functions (e.g. SwiGLUE) that do not naturally induce sparsity; almost all activations are non-zero. However, we observed that activations in Gated-MLP layers tend to cluster “near” zero, suggesting that many weights of MLP layers minimally affect downstream operations.

user.name: Azalia Mirhoseini
user.description: Assistant Professor of CS at Stanford, Senior Staff Research Scientist at Google DeepMind. Prev: Anthropic, Google Brain

entities.text: In a Gated-MLP block, two weight tensors W_up and W_down follow W_gate. We can think of W_gate as a "router" and the columns/rows of W_up and W_down as "experts". As such, we can ignore weights of W_up and W_down and bypass computations if W_gate’s activations are sparse. We achieve this by establishing a percentile threshold (e.g. 50%) for each Gated-MLP layer, and keeping the activations whose absolute values fall within that upper percentile. Using our custom GPU kernel, we then only load and compute the necessary weights of W_up and W_down.

user.name: Azalia Mirhoseini
user.description: Assistant Professor of CS at Stanford, Senior Staff Research Scientist at Google DeepMind. Prev: Anthropic, Google Brain

entities.text: Key results: Without any fine-tuning, and with 50% activation sparsity for MLP layers, CATS maintains strong zero-shot performance (with an avg 1.5% drop on a suite of evals). Furthermore, with minimal fine-tuning on general (not task-specific) text data, CATS performs similarly to the original model, while lowering inference (generation) latency by 15%.

In fact, the single most surprising thing to me after reading the paper is that this is the first thing of exactly this kind that I’ve seen. One way to think about this is that our gradient descent techniques overall are still quite crude! There’s lots of room for optimization beyond/outside the current standard approach to pre-training. 

Possibly this exact result is already well known inside one or more of the foundation labs.

user.name: Daniel Kaiser
user.description: ml since 2012. also cs, phil, econ, geopol, law. normativity is fiction, reject it.

entities.text:
True. And important to keep in mind.

In this case, though, if specific layers provide very little value to the output, evaluated quantitatively in the context of two different standard measures, why would we assume that the layers add value in other eval contexts?

Or are we suggesting that the base model was already overfitting, so these measures are just bad for *any* evaluation of llama-2 (and the other models used in the paper)?

A bunch of people have posted responses to this paper that are similar. And this take may be correct!

But to me, the Occam’s razor intuition here is that our training techniques are still pretty basic and might tend to, for example, concentrate the useful activations in surprisingly small subsets of model weights. 

Maybe most of our “dense” SOTA LLMs today are, in fact, MOEs that we forgot to add routers to. :-)

user.name: Shannon Sands

entities.text:
I find these insights quite accurate.

We don't need (most) of these things, but we need slightly **different** components from these things at different tokens in our sequences.

For instance, certain tokens can skip an FFN while other tokens need that FFN, and vice versa.

The problem is that the pattern which token needs which computation is hard to get right.

Even if we can get the patterns right, these "non-uniform" and heterogeneous computations are hard to implement efficiently.

At the end of the day, GPUs are beast matmul machines, and it happens that matmuls can accomodate many different patterns quite well.

Why 5.4B?

This size allows for:
-bf16 inference on 24GB VRAM
-Q8 or Q6 inference on 6GB VRAM
-Q5 inference on 4GB VRAM
-Fine-tuning on ... well, with less VRAM than an 8B model

Img = model before healing

entities.text:
How important is layer pruning for deeper layer in LLM training ❓

How big is the impact of it on reducing compute resource for LLM training/finetuning. 🤔

This nice paper (from March-2024) explores it - "The Unreasonable Ineffectiveness of the Deeper Layers"

👨‍🔧 "The model’s memory footprint and inference time decreases linearly with the number of removed layers.4 This makes layer pruning a powerful tool, especially if the model’s performance is robust to dropping layers.

👨‍🔧 All the efficiency methods – pruning, PEFT and quantization – can be effectively combined with each other. Thus, in this work each experiment was performed on a single A100 GPU and is easily accessible to the open source and academic communities.

💡 The robustness of models to removing the deeper layers, the sharp transition in performance on downstream knowledge tasks (e.g. MMLU and BoolQ), and the smooth behavior of the autoregressive loss with respect to those pruning fractions, altogether suggest that the shallow layers may play a critical role in storing knowledge."

entities.text:
I was injured by a massive blast which caused a cluster of cells in the middle of my brain to constantly misfire. 
Across 2 1/2 years my brain rewired itself from the standard spaghetti bowl of connections to having one superhighway circle around the outside where all activity traveled. 
Functional MRI was completely wicked to look at, doctors were all wigging out, it was like the entire middle of my brain had a hole in it and all normal brain activity had found a way to function on just the outer rim. 
Back then (2010-2013), the science was really new. Most neurologists didn’t believe in the absurdity of symptoms that I was experiencing. A handful did though, and pointed me to Oliver Sacks as my first relief to help me understand how absurd the brain can be. If you’re interested in these types of stories, I’d suggest you read some of his work. 

The Man Who Mistook His Wife For A Hat: And Other Clinical Tales
a.co/d/eiff3RQ

entities.text:
🎭Recent work shows that models’ inductive biases for 'simpler' features may lead to shortcut learning. 

What do 'simple' vs 'complex' features look like? What roles do they play in generalization?

Our new paper explores these questions.
arxiv.org/pdf/2407.06076
#Neurips2024

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: Qualitative Analysis of “Meta-feature” (cluster of features) Complexity. (Left) A 2D UMAP projection displaying the 10,000 extracted features. The features are organized into 150 clusters using K-means clustering applied to the feature dictionary D. 30 clusters were selected for analysis of features at different complexity levels. (Right) For each Meta-feature cluster, we compute the average complexity score. This allows us to classify the features based on their complexity according to the model. Notably, simple features are often akin to color detectors (e.g., grass, sky) and detectors for low-frequency patterns (e.g., bokeh detector) or lines. In contrast, complex features encompass parts or structured objects, as well as features resembling shape.

user.name: Thomas Fel
user.description: Explainability, Computer Vision, Neuro-AI. Research Fellow @KempnerInst, @Harvard. Prev. @tserre lab, @Google, @GoPro. Crêpe lover.

entities.text:
Our journey began with a metric that leverages 𝒱-information to measure feature complexity. 
It captures the computational effort required to construct a feature. Simply put, if a feature appears in the penultimate layer, how many layers were needed to build it?

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
(Top) Complexity score measuring the computational effort needed for the model to compute a feature z.

(Bottom) Simple vs. Complex Features. Shown is an example of three features extracted using an overcomplete dictionary on the penultimate layer of a ResNet50 trained on ImageNet. Although
all three features can be extracted from the final layer of a ResNet50, some features, such as z1, seem to respond to color, which can be linearly extractable directly from the input. In contrast, z2, z3
visualization appear more “Complex”, responding to more diverse stimuli.

user.name: Thomas Fel
user.description: Explainability, Computer Vision, Neuro-AI. Research Fellow @KempnerInst, @Harvard. Prev. @tserre lab, @Google, @GoPro. Crêpe lover.

entities.text: From analyzing 10,000 features in an IN trained model via Overcomplete Dictionary Learning, we found a range from simple to complex: simple features often detect colors (like sky or sea), lines, bokeh, or watermarks, while complex ones capture intricate patterns or object parts.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
(Left) same umap projection as in the first tweet
(Right) visualization of 5 clusters of meta-features showing top-activating images and feature visualzation.

user.name: Thomas Fel
user.description: Explainability, Computer Vision, Neuro-AI. Research Fellow @KempnerInst, @Harvard. Prev. @tserre lab, @Google, @GoPro. Crêpe lover.

entities.text: When are simple vs. complex features learned? We found that simpler features dominate early in training. As training progresses, more complex features gradually emerge, suggesting a hierarchical development of feature complexity over time.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: Correlation graph between feature complexity and training time needed to be available

user.name: Thomas Fel
user.description: Explainability, Computer Vision, Neuro-AI. Research Fellow @KempnerInst, @Harvard. Prev. @tserre lab, @Google, @GoPro. Crêpe lover.

entities.text: Where do complex features flow in the network? Simple features bypass the visual hierarchy via residual connections; they are being "teleported" to deeper layers. Complex features emerge gradually through the network.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Simple Features Teleported by Residuals. (Left) CKA between residual branch activations and final concept value. For simple
concepts, beyond a certain layer (block 3), the
residual already carries nearly all the information,
effectively teleporting it to the last layer. (Right)
Conversely, for complex features, both the main
and residual branches gradually construct the features during the forward pass.

user.name: Thomas Fel
user.description: Explainability, Computer Vision, Neuro-AI. Research Fellow @KempnerInst, @Harvard. Prev. @tserre lab, @Google, @GoPro. Crêpe lover.

entities.text: How does feature complexity relate to feature importance? Surprisingly, complex features are often less important for the model's decisions. Models show a preference for simpler features, aligning with the simplicity bias observed in prior studies.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Simplicity bias appears during training. Complexity vs. Importance of 10,000 features
extracted from a ResNet50 at Epochs 1 and 90 of training. In Epoch 1, important features are not
necessarily simple and seem uniformly distributed. In contrast, by the end of training, there is a clear
simplicity bias, consistent with numerous studies: the model prefers to rely on simpler features.

user.name: Thomas Fel
user.description: Explainability, Computer Vision, Neuro-AI. Research Fellow @KempnerInst, @Harvard. Prev. @tserre lab, @Google, @GoPro. Crêpe lover.

entities.text: This leads us to the discovery of an interesting 𝗦𝗲𝗱𝗶𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 phenomenon. Important features emerge at earlier layers during training, settling like sediment, as if the model is self-compressing or simplifying his most important features.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Important features are being compressed
by the neural network: Levin Machine hypothesis. The average complexity of 10,000 features
extracted independently at each epoch increases rapidly before stabilizing (the black curve shows the
average). However, among the top-1% of features in terms of importance, complexity decreases over
time, as if the model is self-compressing or simplifying, akin to a sedimentation process.

user.name: Thomas Fel
user.description: Explainability, Computer Vision, Neuro-AI. Research Fellow @KempnerInst, @Harvard. Prev. @tserre lab, @Google, @GoPro. Crêpe lover.

entities.text: Think of it as a "Sedimentation process" where foundational features solidify early, providing a base for more complex feature construction. Important features initially available at layer 10 become progressively accessible at layers 9, 8, and so on...

entities.text:
The researchers wanted to study the complexity of features learned by deep neural networks, specifically a ResNet50 model trained on the ImageNet dataset. They aimed to understand the types of features the model learns, where and when they emerge during training, and how they relate to the model's decision-making.

The findings suggest that deep neural networks have a natural tendency to leverage simpler features, which may contribute to shortcut learning and biases in the models. The researchers propose that the model undergoes a "sedimentation process," where important features are gradually simplified and made more accessible earlier in the network.

full paper:
openread.academy/en/paper/readi…

user.name: Brad Caldwell
user.description: Studying how the brain makes consciousness with particular emphasis on how it makes the 3D geometries within perceptual space ("cognitive map").

entities.text: We have again and again found that you can remove major parts of an LLM and still get the same results.
arxiv.org/abs/2403.17887

Then the surprising bit is that many of these neurons are not actually learning, but are providing a "path to learn" for the other important neurons via passing the gradient around efficiently. 

That's why pruning works so efficiently.

There are certainly many features and scenarios these pruned away neurons contribute to that our benchmarks cannot capture, but still, it is surprising that people have been able to remove as much as 80% of a model's layers with little to no effect on performance.

Abstract: <1788270205870703089> suggested a quantized 70B LLaMa 2 model ([[huggingface.co/nisten/covasna]]) demonstrating practical application of quantization, similar to the paper's use of QLoRA for efficient experimentation on a single GPU.
<1788270493407301705> added that the 4-bit quantized version is 22GB and coherent, further highlighting the feasibility of quantization techniques for large language models.
<1793378522331062463> shared a visually enhanced version of the paper ([[synthical.com/abs/2311.01906]]) which improves accessibility for readers.
Literature review: <1775601728848814176> suggested that the HTSR theory, presented in a NeurIPS 2023 talk [[youtube.com/watch?v=ZT0yZ-…]], predicted the ineffectiveness of deeper layers, providing valuable prior context for the paper's findings.
<1788257659029754175> shared a paper [[huggingface.co/chargoddard/ll…]] that was used for pruning the model discussed in the current research, offering insights into the pruning methodology.
Other discussions mentioned potentially relevant resources like LLMpedia and the weightwatcher.ai leaderboard, but their specific connections to the paper's core findings were not explicitly stated.
General: <1772837404015026569> summarized the paper's key findings on the surprising effectiveness of pruning deeper layers in LLMs without significant performance degradation [[ift.tt/HYV5IES]]. This complements the paper by providing a concise overview of its core contributions.

<1794927369398239736> demonstrated the practical application of the paper's findings by pruning and healing a Llama3-5.4B-Instruct model, referencing the paper [[arxiv.org/abs/2403.17887]] for guidance. This extends the paper's impact by showcasing a real-world implementation of its proposed techniques.
<1774519571090755621> offered a dark mode version of the paper [[synthical.com/abs/2403.17887…]], enhancing accessibility for readers. This complements the paper by improving its readability.

Literature review: <1773345814796013919> and <1773344443266924716> suggested that "ResiDual" [[arxiv.org/abs/2304.14802]] provides a theoretical explanation for the paper's findings by analyzing representation collapse in deeper layers of Transformers with Pre-LN, potentially explaining the observed ineffectiveness.

<1772909797467127893> shared work on PEFT for retraining after pruning [[arxiv.org/abs/2312.15230]], directly relevant to the paper's methodology and offering potential improvements or alternative approaches.

<1773354806519730590> highlighted their work on training shallower LLMs (jpetty.org/depth), offering a contrasting perspective by exploring the effectiveness of shallower architectures from the outset rather than pruning pre-trained models.

Results: <1773304893542936660> pointed out that the comparison with Chinchilla, which uses C4, makes sense given the paper's assumption of infinite data. However, with finite data, the reduction in size would be smaller, and direct training of a smaller model might be more beneficial, albeit potentially more expensive. <1773400764666335657> clarified that the study aimed to improve the efficiency of existing models and explore parameter efficiency and the impact of overtraining on pruning. <1773401279978480083> suggested using a baseline corresponding to the model's training set size if known.

<1818538060633514011> argued that the paper is misleading, as depth-wise pruning harms state tracking abilities in practice, citing failed attempts to heal pruned layers. <1818538981534949866> questioned this, citing the paper's findings on token cosine similarity. <1818539239019102329> countered that cosine similarity doesn't reflect actual model behavior or loss function values, which worsened in their reproduction. <1818540037031559221> cautioned against claims of 50% pruning with minimal quality loss if not reproducible, while <1818539455285698844> suggested width-wise pruning as a more optimal approach.
Accuracy on qa benchmarks: <1775647318739464215> pointed out that the stable scores on MMLU and BoolQ don't necessarily indicate the model's abilities are unaffected, but rather that a subset of question-answering abilities remains intact.  <1775647318739464215> also noted a slight performance drop in these datasets. <1775717794908094823> clarified that the study focuses on the robustness of QA performance, acknowledging the observed phase transition and the subtle performance changes.

<1788248183019323523> expressed skepticism about the adequacy of current evaluation methods, suggesting that removing 40% of the layers should have a more noticeable impact. <1788258657022714342> countered that the results are supported by both MMLU and BoolQ evaluations and a plausible underlying mechanism. <1788258657022714342> also highlighted the novelty of the findings and speculated about their potential implications for pre-training techniques.
Loss on next-token predictions: <1773092418964910535> questioned the implications of the steadily increasing C4 validation loss after healing, even with a fraction of layers dropped. They pointed out that this observation seems to contradict the relatively stable MMLU & BoolQ accuracies, suggesting a potential disconnect between calibration/other capabilities and the measured benchmark performance.

Abstract: <1788265327446331541> suggested that the findings could inspire new dropout layers or activation functions that reduce neuron precision, mimicking the effect of layer pruning. <1788272450851230127> wondered about the extent of precision reduction possible without significant performance degradation.

<1787266562438611177> noted that reproducing the study's results with L3 70b required substantial QLoRA healing, raising questions about the role of shallow vs. deeper layers. <1787268061927502162> interpreted the lack of shortened models in practice as evidence that deeper layers, despite appearing ineffective in the study, play a crucial role.
Intuition: <1773102729872753151> found that the middle layers (25-60%) contain high information related to encoding, while the last layer has exceptionally high information related to decoding.  They also found it surprising that the second to last layer (N-1) has very little information.
Results: <1788258657022714342> highlighted the novelty of the paper's approach to optimization, suggesting potential in refining gradient descent techniques. <1788277748105965761> added that techniques like dropouts and layer pruning could enhance the robustness of the results.

<1774917689930093030> pointed out the undertraining of LLMs and questioned the significant quality improvement from increasing model size. <1775145362916884745> suggested that the internal structure of LLMs might be sparse, contributing to this phenomenon.
Loss on next-token predictions: <1779569444790137019> conducted further experiments on layer pruning strategies like ShortGPT and LaCO, finding them effective for decision-making tasks but less so for generation tasks.  <1779569598825996637> adds that a drop in perplexity provides evidence for this.
Discussion and future directions: <1775599577950790136> questioned the paper's interpretation, arguing that the lack of performance degradation after removing deeper layers doesn't necessarily imply their uselessness, but rather their lack of benefit for the specific benchmarks used.

<1788331595608596681> suggested that many AI functions don't require complex deeper layers, but these layers are easier to train with gradient descent. They compared this to human brains, where unused components can be eliminated after training for efficiency.

Other users discussed the balance between model depth and width. <1787262585429004338> argued for deeper models, while <1787268782400196688> proposed prioritizing depth followed by widening through techniques like Mixture of Experts (MoE).
General: <1775897500161114504> suggests that the paper's findings, along with other recent research on heavy quantization, double descent, and training small models from large model instructions, point towards a common underlying phenomenon related to model convergence and over-parameterization.

Abstract: <1773071929231933544> questioned if the lack of performance impact after pruning half of the layers in LLMs is due to the limited size of evaluation datasets. <1773456761233805637> wondered if this could explain the phase-transition behavior observed in the study.
Introduction: <1775717794908094823> clarified that the paper argues the QA performance isn't *degraded* by pruning, but acknowledges a phase transition. They also noted the next-token prediction loss shows a phase transition without healing and increases linearly with healing.  Further benchmarks are planned.

<1787266788012556473> expressed confusion about the results seeming to contradict earlier findings on copying layers. <1787268319222874473> asked for clarification on which specific results were being compared.
Method: <1773316251772703030> questioned why smaller networks trained from scratch don't achieve the same performance as pruned larger networks. <1773457620042715278> suggested that residual connections might encourage near-zero layers, making them harder to find through direct optimization. <1776855156044317003> shared a related paper suggesting some weights are used in training but not inference.

<1772805343577276784> wondered why hyperparameter tuning doesn't identify these inefficiencies. <1772813812464513433> explained that pruning happens *after* pre-training, and reaching the final pruned architecture through direct training might be impossible.
Results: <1773935560555413724> questioned if the performance drop shown in the chart indicates the model's capacity limit, suggesting that models like phi/mistral might be trained more relative to their size, making them less robust to layer drops.  <1773935560555413724> also asked why not design lower layers wider than top layers. <1774123828861350047> responded that the impact of overtraining on pruning ability is still uncertain, having tested LLaMA(-1) models with similar phase transitions as Llama-2.  Regarding layer width, <1774123870036844768> pointed to a paper suggesting non-uniform widths can hinder training, especially in non-residual networks.

Critique.Results: The authors explored pruning large language models (LLMs) by removing less important layers to improve efficiency. They tested various LLMs (2.7B-70B parameters) and used QLoRA for "healing" the pruned models with C4 data.  Model performance was evaluated on MMLU and BoolQ benchmarks.
Critique.Accuracy on qa benchmarks: The authors investigated the impact of removing layers from large language models (LLMs) on question-answering performance.  They observed a surprising robustness to layer removal, with performance remaining stable even after pruning a significant fraction of layers, before a sharp drop to random guessing.
Critique.Loss on next-token predictions: The authors investigated the effect of layer pruning on language models. They found that while pruning significantly impacts downstream task performance (like question answering), the model's ability to predict the next token (measured by cross-entropy loss) can be largely restored through a "healing" process.

Perspective.Abstract: The authors investigated the role of different layers in LLMs by pruning layers and observing the impact on performance. Surprisingly, they found that a significant portion of deeper layers could be removed with minimal performance drop after fine-tuning, suggesting potential inefficiencies in current training methods.
Perspective.Intuition: The authors discuss the impact of pruning layers in residual networks, hypothesizing that deeper layers can be pruned with greater success due to the slowly changing nature of representations in those layers.
Perspective.Results: The authors explored pruning deeper layers of Large Language Models (LLMs). They tested various LLMs (Llama-2, Qwen, Mistral, Phi-2) and evaluated performance on question-answering benchmarks (MMLU, BoolQ).  Pruned models were "healed" using QLoRA and fine-tuned on the C4 dataset.
Perspective.Loss on next-token predictions: The authors investigated the impact of layer pruning on language models. They found that while pruning can significantly degrade performance on some tasks, the models' ability to predict the next token (measured by cross-entropy loss) remains relatively unaffected after a "healing" process.
Perspective.Discussion and future directions: The authors explored the effectiveness of deeper layers in LLMs. They found that pruning these layers didn't significantly impact performance on question-answering tasks but did affect perplexity. They hypothesized that deeper layers might be more crucial for reasoning tasks and tested this on benchmarks like GSM8K and HellaSwag.
Perspective.General: The authors explored how knowledge is stored in large language models (LLMs). They found that a significant portion of the deeper layers in these models can be removed without substantially impacting performance, suggesting potential inefficiencies in current training methods or a key role for shallower layers in knowledge storage.

Q&A.Abstract: The authors explored how knowledge is stored in LLMs by pruning layers and observing the impact on performance. Surprisingly, they found that removing up to half of the layers resulted in minimal performance degradation after fine-tuning.
Q&A.Introduction: The authors propose a pruning method for large language models (LLMs) that removes deeper layers based on similarity between layer representations. They found that a significant portion of deeper layers can be pruned with minimal impact on question-answering performance, but other tasks are more sensitive to pruning.
Q&A.Method: The authors explore why pruning deeper layers of neural networks often doesn't significantly impact performance. They offer intuitions for this phenomenon and describe their pruning method.
Q&A.Results: The authors explored pruning strategies for Large Language Models (LLMs), evaluating performance on question-answering benchmarks. They used models like Llama-2, Qwen, Mistral, and Phi, applying "healing" with QLoRA and fine-tuning on the C4 dataset.  Evaluations were done on MMLU and BoolQ.
